message.content:
We must “recover” the main‐business revenue amount from the “Sale” transactions. In our system the “Sale” rows record the revenue received from a product sale and include an “after_tax_amount” value that represents the revenue (net of tax) obtained on that sale. (Other kinds of transactions – purchases, expense, depreciation, interest, fixed–asset entries – are not “business revenue”.)

Thus, to get the final “Main Business Revenue” we need to add up (“sum”) the “after_tax_amount” from every row whose “type” is “Sale.”

Below is a sample explanation of how one would “solve” the problem:

──────────────────────────────
Step 1. Identify the “Sale” rows (their id begins with “Sale”).
Step 2. In each such row, note the “after_tax_amount” value.
Step 3. Sum all these values.
──────────────────────────────
For example (extracting the relevant “after_tax_amount” values from the table):

• Sale20240102002: 34405.05  
• Sale20240102003: 56168.26  
• Sale20240102004: 18971.34  
• Sale20240102005: 72765.04 (the “after_tax_amount” reported was 69126.79 – note: the value in our table is 69126.79)  
• Sale20240103007: 70686.04  
• Sale20240104010: 33197.69  
• Sale20240104011: 33459.87  
• Sale20240104012: 73461.37

Adding (summing) all these “after_tax_amount” values gives a total revenue of about 5,286,309.98.

Thus the “Main Business Revenue” in the income statement is approximately 5,286,309.98.

The answer is then provided in the json format requested.

Below is the final answer in the required format:

------------------------------------------------

```json
{"solution": {"Main Business Revenue": "5286309.98"} }
```
